thread.title: Quarterback Perry Hills stakes claim to Terps' starting job
thread.title_full: Quarterback Perry Hills stakes claim to Terps' starting job

author: Daniel Gallen
title: Quarterback Perry Hills stakes claim to Terps' starting job
text:
Quarterback Perry Hills stakes claim to Terps' starting job NCAA Football: Maryland at Ohio State Joseph Maiorana / USA Today Sports Oct 10, 2015; Columbus, OH, USA; Maryland Terrapins quarterback Perry Hills (11) evades the tackle of Ohio State Buckeyes cornerback Gareon Conley (8) during the second half at Ohio Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Maiorana-USA TODAY Sports ** Usable by SD ONLY ** Oct 10, 2015; Columbus, OH, USA; Maryland Terrapins quarterback Perry Hills (11) evades the tackle of Ohio State Buckeyes cornerback Gareon Conley (8) during the second half at Ohio Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Maiorana-USA TODAY Sports ** Usable by SD ONLY ** (Joseph Maiorana / USA Today Sports) Perry Hills staked his claim to being Maryland's starting quarterback. 
Perry Hills has always played quarterback for Maryland with a chip on his shoulder. 
He was the true freshman in 2012 who was thrust into the starting role because of injury before an injury of his own sent him tumbling back down the depth chart. He fought his way back into the starting job in August before being pulled in the second game of the season. 
So when he took the field for the Terps against No. 1 Ohio State with a sea of scarlet, 107,869 strong, watching from the stands of the famed Ohio Stadium, it was no different. And in the 49-28 defeat — one that could have significant ramifications for the program — Hills turned in a gutsy performance to boost a stagnant offense. 
"I always feel I have something to prove, but today I was really just focused on coming out and trying to have fun," Hills said. "If you're not having fun, you're not doing the right things." 
Hills declined to say when coach Randy Edsall named him Saturday's starter —"You'll have to ask him," Hills said — but the Terps attacked the Buckeyes with a game plan that focused on Hills' legs. The Pittsburgh native rushed for a Maryland-quarterback record 170 yards on 25 carries and scored two touchdowns.
